migrationStep.completed1: Congratulations! You have completed the first of two migration steps.
migrationStep.completed2:
Don't forget to invite your followers to sign up for OpenPortability. In 1 minute they can be reconnected to your account, even without their archive.
Phase 2 of the reconnection will occur in a few days. Depending on your preferences, you will receive an email notification or can follow the launch on our X, BlueSky and Mastodon accounts.
Stay tuned, exciting surprises await you!
migrationStep.nextSteps: Complete the following steps to sail towards new horizons!

upload.title: Import your X/Twitter archive to continue your journey
upload.action: Drop or select your X/Twitter archive here
upload.description:
Three data formats are accepted:
- your original X archive if <1GB (in Zip format)
- the following.js and follower.js files TOGETHER and not zipped,
- split versions of these files for large archives (following-part*.js + follower-part*.js).
 In all cases, only the followers/following lists are transmitted

loading.uploading: Do not leave the page, import is in progress

upload.loading-uploading: Stay on the page, import in progress

logoCNRS.alt: CNRS, National Center for Scientific Research

helpModal.title: How to get your X/Twitter archive?
helpModal.description: To get your X/Twitter archive, follow these steps:
steps: Sign in to your X/Twitter account
Go to "More" in the left menu
Click on "Settings and support" then "Settings and privacy"
Under "Your account", select "Download an archive of your data"
X/Twitter will send you an email when your archive is ready to download
Once downloaded, you can import the .zip file here
helpModal.note: Note: X/Twitter may take up to 24 hours to prepare your archive.

firstSeen.title: Welcome!
firstSeen.description:
You are about to register yourself on the social web GPS and exercise your right to data portability from X to BlueSky and/or Mastodon while participating in a social media research project. It will take 5 minutes.

OpenPortability will map your digital identities and allow you to gradually recreate your community on BlueSky and/or Mastodon, without affecting your X account.

As other users sign up for OpenPortability, the links referenced on X will be recreated on BlueSky or Mastodon with their consent. Feel free to encourage your followers to do the same!

This "copy" of your social network may take several days.
If you choose to appear on the social web GPS (see preferences), our users will be able to discover your account and follow you.

By using OpenPortability, you accept that your data be processed in accordance with {lien} and consent to the possible transfer of your data outside the European Union (e.g. BlueSky servers).

challenge.title: The Challenge
challenge.content: How to position 658,000 accounts in a 2D plane so that similar accounts are close together?

node2vec.title: Step 1: Node2Vec (Graph → 64D)
node2vec.content: Node2Vec is a graph representation algorithm inspired by Word2Vec. The idea: treat 'random walks' in the graph as sentences, and nodes as words. Each node is represented by a 64-dimensional vector capturing its structural position in the graph.

umap.title: Step 2: UMAP (64D → 2D)
umap.subtitle: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection
umap.content: UMAP preserves both global AND local graph structure. Faster than t-SNE (essential for 658k points), deterministic results (scientific reproducibility), better distance preservation (clusters remain coherent).
umap.howItWorks: UMAP builds a topological graph in 64D space, then optimizes it in 2D by: preserving close neighborhoods (local structure), respecting global topology (manifold learning), minimizing cross-entropy between the two representations.

result.title: Final Result
result.content: Accounts that frequently interact naturally end up close in the 2D visual space, while preserving the global community structure.

summary.title: Summary
points: Node2Vec captures 'who is connected to whom'
UMAP projects this information into 2D so your eye can interpret it
The 64 intermediate dimensions capture nuances that 2D alone could not

communities.title: Community Detection Methods
communities.subtitle: Identifying thematic structures using a hybrid algorithm + semantic approach

step1.title: Step 1 - Structural Detection
step1.content: We use K-Means with k=50 applied directly to the 64-dimensional embedding vectors produced by node2vec.
step1.why: The embeddings already capture the graph structure (proximity = similarity). K-Means identifies clusters in the Euclidean space of embeddings. k=50 initial clusters allow fine granularity, later aggregated into 10 meta-communities for interpretability.
step1.advantages: Spatial coherence: clusters are visually contiguous. Flexibility: easy adjustment of cluster count.

step2.title: Step 2 - Semantic Annotation
step2.content: Extraction from a dictionary of verified accounts with twitter_id + descriptions. For each detected community: retrieval of verified account descriptions, cleaning (stop words removal), TF-IDF extraction of dominant keywords, aggregation of 50 clusters into 10 thematic meta-communities, manual labeling based on recurring terms.

privacy_policy.title: Data Protection Information Note
privacy_policy.subtitle: Institute of Complex Systems Paris Ile de France | January 2025
privacy_policy.content:
CNRS ISC PIF

Data protection information note in the context of scientific research Open Portability Project

Social networks and in particular Twitter (now X) have from the beginning constituted privileged research objects, particularly in the field of computational social sciences.

A historical transition is underway in the landscape of social networks. The centralized model, embodied by X (formerly Twitter), is experiencing a massive exodus of users to alternative platforms such as BlueSky and Mastodon. Several million accounts migrated in a few weeks, marking a major shift towards decentralized and open networks.

This transition is a major social, economic and technological phenomenon which, perhaps, will transform the global digital space and in particular European and could allow Europe to regain some digital sovereignty.

I. Description of the project and processing

The objectives of the research are as follows: to analyze the difference between open and closed micro-blogging digital environments from the perspective of social dynamics and online debates. To study as a case study the ongoing migration between X and spaces based on open protocols AT Protocol and Activity Pub and to study the appropriation of decentralized digital spaces over time (5-year horizon).

The OpenPortability project involves:

  • Data collection for data portability between social networks
  • Data collection for taking a snapshot of the social structure of the X network
  • Data collection for taking snapshots of the social structures of alternative networks
  • Data portability
  • Data processing and analysis

II. Data collection, recipients and retention

Data collected directly from individuals and processed are:

  • Digital identifiers on social networks (user name ID)
  • Profile names on social networks
  • Email addresses

Bluesky's personal data protection policy is available on: https://bsky.social/about/support/privacy-policy

Mastodon's personal data protection policy is available on https://joinmastodon.org/servers

III. Security measures

To ensure data confidentiality and protection, measures are taken in application of the State's information systems security policy, applied to CNRS. Data is hosted in France on CNRS servers.

IV. Exercise of your rights

You can access and obtain copies of data concerning you, object to the processing of this data or have it corrected. You also have the right to restrict the processing of your data. You can exercise these rights by contacting the data controller at the Institute of Complex Systems-Paris Ile de France, located at 113 rue Nationale 75013 Paris, or using the contact form available on https://openportability.org/

You can also contact the CNRS Data Protection Officer (DPO) at the following address: CNRS - Data Protection Service, 2 rue Jean Zay, 54519 Vandoeuvre-lès-Nancy - dpd.demandes@cnrs.fr.

If you believe that your Information Technology and Freedoms rights are not being respected, you have the possibility to file a complaint online with the CNIL, 3 Place de Fontenoy, TSA 80715 – 75334 Paris Cedex 07 (https://www.cnil.fr/).

step1.title: Explore the social graph
step1.description: Navigate among 650,000+ X/Twitter accounts visualized through their connections. Each dot represents an account, colored by community of interest.
step1.controls:
Wheel = Zoom
Click + Drag = Move
Click = Select

step2.title: Three view modes
step2.description: Switch between Discovery (explore everything), Following (your following) and Followers (your followers). Your personal network is highlighted when you select a mode.

step3.title: Lasso selection
step3.description: Draw a selection on the map to discover important accounts in the area. Perfect for exploring communities!
step3.controls:
Click the Lasso tool in the toolbar
Draw a shape
The area stats appear in the panel

step4.title: Reconnection panel
step4.description: The right panel displays accounts you can reconnect with on Bluesky and Mastodon. Select and click 'Reconnect' to follow them.

step5.title: Customize your view
